g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Mounted volumes and env-vars

External data is often injected into pods via environment variables or projected volumes.
These are typically read-only and can include ConfigMaps, Secrets, or dynamic runtime
values like the pod IP or namespace.

When a pod needs to interact with the Kubernetes API, a service account token is
automatically mounted as a projected volume. Ensure proper RBAC scoping for the
associated service account to avoid privilege escalation." tags="pri-2" slug="mounts"/>
g.data-help:
Mounted volumes and env-vars
External data is often injected into pods via environment variables or projected volumes. These are typically read-only and can include ConfigMaps, Secrets, or dynamic runtime values like the pod IP or namespace.
When a pod needs to interact with the Kubernetes API, a service account token is automatically mounted as a projected volume. Ensure proper RBAC scoping for the associated service account to avoid privilege escalation.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Network interfaces (overlay)

Normal kubernetes network is done using an overlay using a CNI (Container Network Interface),
like Cilium, Flannel, Calico and many others. They have various functionality and security.
Example, some CNIs doesnt support egress network policies, some uses eBPF a lot, some iptables." tags="pri-2" slug="overlay"/>
g.data-help:
Network interfaces (overlay)
Normal kubernetes network is done using an overlay using a CNI (Container Network Interface), like Cilium, Flannel, Calico and many others. They have various functionality and security. Example, some CNIs doesnt support egress network policies, some uses eBPF a lot, some iptables.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Traffic after filters

This is the raw, decrypted traffic that reaches the application after passing
through L7 filters or service mesh proxies. At this point, the traffic is no
longer encrypted and can be inspected or modified by sidecars or host-level tools
before delivery to the application process.

Ensure that applications enforce their own validation and security controls,
as traffic is now trusted and inside the protected boundary." tags="pri-3" slug="post-filter-traffic"/>
g.data-help:
Traffic after filters
This is the raw, decrypted traffic that reaches the application after passing through L7 filters or service mesh proxies. At this point, the traffic is no longer encrypted and can be inspected or modified by sidecars or host-level tools before delivery to the application process.
Ensure that applications enforce their own validation and security controls, as traffic is now trusted and inside the protected boundary.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Exposed port

All containers in a pod share the same network namespace and run on the same node.
This allows enforcement of eBPF-based filters and transparent mTLS at the network level.

With sidecars or service mesh integration, unencrypted ports like 80 can safely be
exposed internally. Encryption, authentication, and access control are handled outside
the application, making this a secure and preferred approach for internal services." tags="pri-3" slug="exposed-ports"/>
g.data-help:
Exposed port
All containers in a pod share the same network namespace and run on the same node. This allows enforcement of eBPF-based filters and transparent mTLS at the network level.
With sidecars or service mesh integration, unencrypted ports like 80 can safely be exposed internally. Encryption, authentication, and access control are handled outside the application, making this a secure and preferred approach for internal services.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="The Container Process

Containerized workloads are secured through PodSecurityContext/SecurityContext,
Pod Security Standards (PSA), namespace isolation, and runtime enforcement.
Tools like Falco (eBPF) monitor behavior, while KubeArmor enforces policies.
Enterprise options include Sysdig Secure, Tetragon, Prisma Cloud, and the open-source NeuVector.

Syscalls are restricted by default; escapes often rely on misconfigurations such as
excessive Linux capabilities, unfiltered syscalls, insecure mounts, or relaxed namespace settings.

Linux namespaces isolate PIDs, networking, and other kernel features;
cgroups control CPU/memory and can freeze containers for forensics.

Runtime policies like runAsNonRoot or fixed UID/GID can be set
at the container/pod level or baked into the image." slug="container-process"/>
g.data-help:
The Container Process
Containerized workloads are secured through PodSecurityContext/SecurityContext, Pod Security Standards (PSA), namespace isolation, and runtime enforcement. Tools like Falco (eBPF) monitor behavior, while KubeArmor enforces policies. Enterprise options include Sysdig Secure, Tetragon, Prisma Cloud, and the open-source NeuVector.
Syscalls are restricted by default; escapes often rely on misconfigurations such as excessive Linux capabilities, unfiltered syscalls, insecure mounts, or relaxed namespace settings.
Linux namespaces isolate PIDs, networking, and other kernel features; cgroups control CPU/memory and can freeze containers for forensics.
Runtime policies like runAsNonRoot or fixed UID/GID can be set at the container/pod level or baked into the image.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Sidecar container

Sidecar containers can improve security by isolating responsibilities such as TLS termination,
authentication, or logging from the main app. They are used by some service meshes (e.g., Istio),
but newer approaches like eBPF and ambient meshes offer lower overhead and better scalability.

Sidecars share the same network namespace, allowing secure localhost (127.0.0.1) communication.
They can also enforce policies or proxy traffic, but increase attack surface and resource usage." tags="pri-3" slug="sidecar-container"/>
g.data-help:
Sidecar container
Sidecar containers can improve security by isolating responsibilities such as TLS termination, authentication, or logging from the main app. They are used by some service meshes (e.g., Istio), but newer approaches like eBPF and ambient meshes offer lower overhead and better scalability.
Sidecars share the same network namespace, allowing secure localhost (127.0.0.1) communication. They can also enforce policies or proxy traffic, but increase attack surface and resource usage.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Init container

Init containers enhance security by performing setup tasks before the main container starts,
such as validating configs, downloading secrets, or verifying service dependencies.

They run with separate images and permissions, reducing attack surface in the main container.
Types include wait-for-dependency containers, secret fetchers, permission fixers (e.g., chown volumes),
and environment validators. Since they run sequentially and exit before app start,
they can enforce strict preconditions and avoid persistent exposure." tags="pri-3" slug="init-container"/>
g.data-help:
Init container
Init containers enhance security by performing setup tasks before the main container starts, such as validating configs, downloading secrets, or verifying service dependencies.
They run with separate images and permissions, reducing attack surface in the main container. Types include wait-for-dependency containers, secret fetchers, permission fixers (e.g., chown volumes), and environment validators. Since they run sequentially and exit before app start, they can enforce strict preconditions and avoid persistent exposure.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Ephemeral containers

Ephemeral containers are used for live debugging of running Pods without restarting them.
They provide no guarantees on lifecycle, don't support volumes, and can't be part of normal app logic.
From a security standpoint, they are powerful but riskyif enabled, they allow runtime inspection,
so access should be tightly controlled (e.g., via RBAC).

They share namespaces (like network and PID) with existing containers,
enabling deep introspection but also potential abuse if misused." tags="pri-3" slug="ephemeral-container"/>
g.data-help:
Ephemeral containers
Ephemeral containers are used for live debugging of running Pods without restarting them. They provide no guarantees on lifecycle, don't support volumes, and can't be part of normal app logic. From a security standpoint, they are powerful but riskyif enabled, they allow runtime inspection, so access should be tightly controlled (e.g., via RBAC).
They share namespaces (like network and PID) with existing containers, enabling deep introspection but also potential abuse if misused.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="WASM containers

WASM containers aim to run WebAssembly modules in place of traditional OCI containers,
offering stronger isolation, faster cold starts, and lower resource usage. They don't rely on Linux syscalls,
reducing attack surface and making them ideal for sandboxed, untrusted code. Projects like wasmEdge,
containerd-shim-wasmedge, and Krustlet explore this in Kubernetes.

Long-term, WASM containers could enable safer multi-tenant workloads and portable compute
across cloud, edge, and browser environments." tags="pri-3" slug="wasm-container"/>
g.data-help:
WASM containers
WASM containers aim to run WebAssembly modules in place of traditional OCI containers, offering stronger isolation, faster cold starts, and lower resource usage. They don't rely on Linux syscalls, reducing attack surface and making them ideal for sandboxed, untrusted code. Projects like wasmEdge, containerd-shim-wasmedge, and Krustlet explore this in Kubernetes.
Long-term, WASM containers could enable safer multi-tenant workloads and portable compute across cloud, edge, and browser environments.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Hardened container runtimes

Hardened container runtimes provide additional isolation layers beyond standard
runtimes like runc. For example, gVisor intercepts syscalls and provides a
userspace kernel implementation, while Kata Containers wrap each container in
lightweight virtual machines.

OpenShift Sandbox Containers use Kata under the hood to offer enhanced isolation." tags="pri-3" slug="hardened-runtimes"/>
g.data-help:
Hardened container runtimes
Hardened container runtimes provide additional isolation layers beyond standard runtimes like runc. For example, gVisor intercepts syscalls and provides a userspace kernel implementation, while Kata Containers wrap each container in lightweight virtual machines.
OpenShift Sandbox Containers use Kata under the hood to offer enhanced isolation.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Internal pod egress

Egress traffic from a pod to other services inside the cluster can be controlled
using NetworkPolicies, similar to ingress rules. However, egress rules are often
overlooked, as ingress is more commonly enforced.

Define explicit egress policies to restrict which services a pod can communicate
with, reducing lateral movement and attack surface in case of compromise." tags="pri-2" slug="normal-pod-egress"/>
g.data-help:
Internal pod egress
Egress traffic from a pod to other services inside the cluster can be controlled using NetworkPolicies, similar to ingress rules. However, egress rules are often overlooked, as ingress is more commonly enforced.
Define explicit egress policies to restrict which services a pod can communicate with, reducing lateral movement and attack surface in case of compromise.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Traffic before filters

Traffic before reaching L7 filters (e.g., Envoy) is often encrypted with mTLS.
This makes payload inspection impossible, but metadata such as SNI, client identity,
or source IP can still be used to enforce context-aware ACLs.

Use this metadata to apply fine-grained policies even when the content is opaque." tags="pri-2" slug="pre-filter-traffic"/>
g.data-help:
Traffic before filters
Traffic before reaching L7 filters (e.g., Envoy) is often encrypted with mTLS. This makes payload inspection impossible, but metadata such as SNI, client identity, or source IP can still be used to enforce context-aware ACLs.
Use this metadata to apply fine-grained policies even when the content is opaque.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Network Control

Network policies can enforce L3/L4 restrictions using eBPF or iptables,
while L7 policies are enforced via proxies (e.g., Envoy).

Some CNIs support admin-level policies that cannot be overridden by
namespace users, enabling enforcement of cluster-wide or organizational
security standards." slug="network-control"/>
g.data-help:
Network Control
Network policies can enforce L3/L4 restrictions using eBPF or iptables, while L7 policies are enforced via proxies (e.g., Envoy).
Some CNIs support admin-level policies that cannot be overridden by namespace users, enabling enforcement of cluster-wide or organizational security standards.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1 IngressStack" help="Ingress

Kubernetes Ingress resources configure an ingress controller (e.g., NGINX, HAProxy)
to handle inbound traffic. Controllers support annotations for TLS settings,
authentication, WAF (e.g., ModSecurity), and other security features.

Routing is typically based on SNI (FQDN) and HTTP-layer data such as path,
method, or headers. Secure configuration of the ingress controller is critical,
including rate limiting, header validation, and TLS hardening.

For new designs, prefer Gateway API where possible. Gateway API provides
a more structured and extensible model for routing, policy attachment, and
role separation, and is the main direction of ongoing ecosystem development." slug="ingress-deployment"/>
g.data-help:
Ingress
Kubernetes Ingress resources configure an ingress controller (e.g., NGINX, HAProxy) to handle inbound traffic. Controllers support annotations for TLS settings, authentication, WAF (e.g., ModSecurity), and other security features.
Routing is typically based on SNI (FQDN) and HTTP-layer data such as path, method, or headers. Secure configuration of the ingress controller is critical, including rate limiting, header validation, and TLS hardening.
For new designs, prefer Gateway API where possible. Gateway API provides a more structured and extensible model for routing, policy attachment, and role separation, and is the main direction of ongoing ecosystem development.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="VirtualMachine or other workload-types

Other workload types, such as VirtualMachines (e.g., via KubeVirt), follow the same
security mechanisms as pods: RBAC, network policies, storage classes, and admission control.

They are not inherently more privileged and should be treated like any other workload
with proper isolation, policy enforcement, and monitoring in place." tags="pri-3" slug="vm"/>
g.data-help:
VirtualMachine or other workload-types
Other workload types, such as VirtualMachines (e.g., via KubeVirt), follow the same security mechanisms as pods: RBAC, network policies, storage classes, and admission control.
They are not inherently more privileged and should be treated like any other workload with proper isolation, policy enforcement, and monitoring in place.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Secrets and ConfigMaps

Secrets and ConfigMaps can be encrypted at rest using encryption providers
configured on the API server. The decryption keys are typically stored inside
the cluster, often on disk.

For improved security, use external KMS providers (e.g., HashiCorp Vault, AWS KMS)
to manage keys and prevent key compromise within the cluster." tags="pri-2" slug="cm-and-secret"/>
g.data-help:
Secrets and ConfigMaps
Secrets and ConfigMaps can be encrypted at rest using encryption providers configured on the API server. The decryption keys are typically stored inside the cluster, often on disk.
For improved security, use external KMS providers (e.g., HashiCorp Vault, AWS KMS) to manage keys and prevent key compromise within the cluster.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Validating and Mutating Admission Control

Admission controllers intercept API requests after authentication and authorization,
allowing for policy enforcement. Tools like Kyverno and OPA Gatekeeper can validate
incoming YAML against cluster policies or mutate it to enforce configuration standards
(e.g., securityContext, labels, resource limits).

All resourcesuser-submitted or system-generatedmust pass admission control.
These controllers can also enforce image signature verification (e.g., cosign)
and SLSA provenance checks to prevent untrusted artifacts from being deployed." tags="pri-2" slug="admission-control"/>
g.data-help:
Validating and Mutating Admission Control
Admission controllers intercept API requests after authentication and authorization, allowing for policy enforcement. Tools like Kyverno and OPA Gatekeeper can validate incoming YAML against cluster policies or mutate it to enforce configuration standards (e.g., securityContext, labels, resource limits).
All resourcesuser-submitted or system-generatedmust pass admission control. These controllers can also enforce image signature verification (e.g., cosign) and SLSA provenance checks to prevent untrusted artifacts from being deployed.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="system:masters group

The 'system:masters' group is a built-in Kubernetes group that bypasses the
authorization layer and grants full administrative access to the cluster.

It should only be used for initial bootstrapping or controlled RBAC testing.
Ensure no regular users or service accounts are members of this group.
Monitor and audit usage carefullythis group should be empty in production environments." tags="pri-2" slug="system-masters"/>
g.data-help:
system:masters group
The 'system:masters' group is a built-in Kubernetes group that bypasses the authorization layer and grants full administrative access to the cluster.
It should only be used for initial bootstrapping or controlled RBAC testing. Ensure no regular users or service accounts are members of this group. Monitor and audit usage carefullythis group should be empty in production environments.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Authentication webhook

Authentication webhooks are less commonly used, but can provide additional
control beyond standard RBAC. They allow dynamic authentication decisions
based on external systems or custom logic.

For example, a webhook can reject requests targeting namespaces that match
certain patterns or enforce organization-specific access rules in real time." tags="pri-3" slug="auth-webhook"/>
g.data-help:
Authentication webhook
Authentication webhooks are less commonly used, but can provide additional control beyond standard RBAC. They allow dynamic authentication decisions based on external systems or custom logic.
For example, a webhook can reject requests targeting namespaces that match certain patterns or enforce organization-specific access rules in real time.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Internal API communication

The Kubernetes API should only be accessible to internal system components,
operators, and pods that explicitly require it.

Use default-deny NetworkPolicies to block access by default, and only allow
specific namespaces or service accounts to communicate with the API server.
This minimizes the attack surface and enforces least privilege access." tags="pri-3" slug="internal-api"/>
g.data-help:
Internal API communication
The Kubernetes API should only be accessible to internal system components, operators, and pods that explicitly require it.
Use default-deny NetworkPolicies to block access by default, and only allow specific namespaces or service accounts to communicate with the API server. This minimizes the attack surface and enforces least privilege access.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Kubernetes API

The Kubernetes API is the primary control plane entry point and must be tightly secured.
All access passes through two stages: authentication and authorization.

API call is first ratelimited using <a target=_blank href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/flow-control/">priority and fairness</a>.

Authentication verifies the caller (client certificates, bearer tokens, OIDC, or webhook tokens).
Anonymous requests are allowed by default (should be disabled in production).

Authorization decides if the authenticated identity may act. Kubernetes supports:
- RBAC (Role-Based Access Control): recommended and widely adopted.
- Webhook Authorization: delegate decisions to an external policy engine.
- ABAC (Attribute-Based Access Control): legacy and strongly discouraged; keep only for
 backward compatibility and plan to migrate off it.

RBAC grants fine-grained verbs (GET, CREATE, etc.) over resources and API groups via roles/bindings.
ABAC uses JSON policy files but is harder to audit and operate at scale.

Enable API server audit logging and ship logs to a remote backend for monitoring and incident response." slug="incoming-req"/>
g.data-help: Kubernetes API The Kubernetes API is the primary control plane entry point and must be tightly secured. All access passes through two stages: authentication and authorization. API call is first ratelimited using priority and fairness. Authentication verifies the caller (client certificates, bearer tokens, OIDC, or webhook tokens). Anonymous requests are allowed by default (should be disabled in production). Authorization decides if the authenticated identity may act. Kubernetes supports: - RBAC (Role-Based Access Control): recommended and widely adopted. - Webhook Authorization: delegate decisions to an external policy engine. - ABAC (Attribute-Based Access Control): legacy and strongly discouraged; keep only for backward compatibility and plan to migrate off it. RBAC grants fine-grained verbs (GET, CREATE, etc.) over resources and API groups via roles/bindings. ABAC uses JSON policy files but is harder to audit and operate at scale. Enable API server audit logging and ship logs to a remote backend for monitoring and incident response.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="RBAC

<a target=_blank href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/">RBAC</a> authorizes a request by matching
the caller (User/Group/ServiceAccount) to bindings, which reference roles containing
rules (verbs/resources/apiGroups).

<b>Role and RoleBindings</b>
* Role: used by RoleBinding (same namespace)
* ClusterRole (cluster-scoped): used by ClusterRoleBinding (cluster-wide) or RoleBinding (namespaced)
* RoleBinding (namespaced) can reference Role or ClusterRole
* ClusterRoleBinding (cluster-scoped) can reference only ClusterRole

<b><a target=_blank href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/#referring-to-subjects">Subjects</a></b>
* User (global): not a Kubernetes resource; comes from authentication (cert/OIDC/webhook)
* Group (global): not a resource; assigned by the identity provider
* ServiceAccount (namespaced resource): must include namespace in bindings (also in ClusterRoleBinding). RoleBindings can only use ServiceAccounts from their own namespace

Rules specify <code>apiGroups</code>, <code>resources</code>, <code>resourceNames</code> (optional), and <code>verbs</code> (e.g., get,list,watch,create,update,patch,delete).
Non-resource URLs use <code>nonResourceURLs</code>.

<b>Warnings</b>
* Wildcards: avoid <code>"*"</code> for verbs/resources/apiGroups unless truly needed
* <code>escalate</code> verb (on roles/clusterroles): allows creating/updating roles with permissions beyond your own
* <code>bind</code> verb (on clusterroles): allows binding clusterroles you don't otherwise own
* <code>impersonate</code> verb: restrict tightly; lets callers act as other users/groups/SAs (<a target=_blank href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/authentication/#user-impersonation">Impersonation docs</a>)
* Node/proxy (e.g. nodes/proxy, nodes/*, services/proxy, pods/proxy): Permissions that enable proxying via the API server can look harmless for monitoring, but effectively grant access to node/kubelet (and other proxied) HTTP endpoints. Treat as high-risk: avoid wildcards, scope tightly (resourceNames/namespaces), and only grant if you fully understand the blast radius and the exact endpoints the client can reach. This includes the GET verb!" slug="rbac"/>
g.data-help: RBAC RBAC authorizes a request by matching the caller (User/Group/ServiceAccount) to bindings, which reference roles containing rules (verbs/resources/apiGroups). Role and RoleBindings * Role: used by RoleBinding (same namespace) * ClusterRole (cluster-scoped): used by ClusterRoleBinding (cluster-wide) or RoleBinding (namespaced) * RoleBinding (namespaced) can reference Role or ClusterRole * ClusterRoleBinding (cluster-scoped) can reference only ClusterRole Subjects * User (global): not a Kubernetes resource; comes from authentication (cert/OIDC/webhook) * Group (global): not a resource; assigned by the identity provider * ServiceAccount (namespaced resource): must include namespace in bindings (also in ClusterRoleBinding). RoleBindings can only use ServiceAccounts from their own namespace Rules specify apiGroups, resources, resourceNames (optional), and verbs (e.g., get,list,watch,create,update,patch,delete). Non-resource URLs use nonResourceURLs. Warnings * Wildcards: avoid "*" for verbs/resources/apiGroups unless truly needed * escalate verb (on roles/clusterroles): allows creating/updating roles with permissions beyond your own * bind verb (on clusterroles): allows binding clusterroles you don't otherwise own * impersonate verb: restrict tightly; lets callers act as other users/groups/SAs (Impersonation docs) * Node/proxy (e.g. nodes/proxy, nodes/*, services/proxy, pods/proxy): Permissions that enable proxying via the API server can look harmless for monitoring, but effectively grant access to node/kubelet (and other proxied) HTTP endpoints. Treat as high-risk: avoid wildcards, scope tightly (resourceNames/namespaces), and only grant if you fully understand the blast radius and the exact endpoints the client can reach. This includes the GET verb!

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Cluster to cluster mesh (cluster-mesh)

A cluster-mesh connects multiple Kubernetes clusters to enable cross-cluster
communication with cloud-native networking features. This allows services in
different clusters to communicate as if they were in the same network.

Traffic can be encrypted using mTLS and authenticated using workload identities
unique to each cluster. With proper setup, standard Kubernetes NetworkPolicies
can be enforced across cluster boundaries." tags="pri-3" slug="cluster-mesh"/>
g.data-help:
Cluster to cluster mesh (cluster-mesh)
A cluster-mesh connects multiple Kubernetes clusters to enable cross-cluster communication with cloud-native networking features. This allows services in different clusters to communicate as if they were in the same network.
Traffic can be encrypted using mTLS and authenticated using workload identities unique to each cluster. With proper setup, standard Kubernetes NetworkPolicies can be enforced across cluster boundaries.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Secure CNI (e.g., Cilium)

Use a CNI plugin that supports fine-grained network policies and visibility,
such as Cilium with eBPF. Define a baseline deny-all policy and explicitly allow
only required traffic.

Default Kubernetes network policies are namespace-scoped and may not cover all scenarios." tags="pri-2" slug="cilium"/>
g.data-help:
Secure CNI (e.g., Cilium)
Use a CNI plugin that supports fine-grained network policies and visibility, such as Cilium with eBPF. Define a baseline deny-all policy and explicitly allow only required traffic.
Default Kubernetes network policies are namespace-scoped and may not cover all scenarios.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="API to etcd Communication

The Kubernetes API server communicates with etcd to persist cluster state.
Read operations (e.g., GET) fetch data directly and do not trigger admission controllers.

Kubernetes also includes the built-in Pod Security Admission (PSA) controller, which
enforces the Pod Security Standards (privileged, baseline, restricted) on all created
or updated Pods without requiring external webhooks/controllers (it's builtin to the apiserver).

Admission controllers only intercept mutating operations (e.g., CREATE, UPDATE, DELETE).
This means read access must be tightly controlled via RBAC/ABAC, since policies cannot
be enforced via admission webhooks for those requests." tags="pri-2" slug="api-to-etcd"/>
g.data-help:
API to etcd Communication
The Kubernetes API server communicates with etcd to persist cluster state. Read operations (e.g., GET) fetch data directly and do not trigger admission controllers.
Kubernetes also includes the built-in Pod Security Admission (PSA) controller, which enforces the Pod Security Standards (privileged, baseline, restricted) on all created or updated Pods without requiring external webhooks/controllers (it's builtin to the apiserver).
Admission controllers only intercept mutating operations (e.g., CREATE, UPDATE, DELETE). This means read access must be tightly controlled via RBAC/ABAC, since policies cannot be enforced via admission webhooks for those requests.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="etcd

etcd stores the entire state of the Kubernetes cluster and must be protected accordingly.
Enable encryption at rest using the API server's encryption provider configuration.

Access to etcd should be strictly limited to the API server. Ensure mutual TLS is enabled,
and never expose etcd directly to the network." tags="pri-3" slug="etcd"/>
g.data-help:
etcd
etcd stores the entire state of the Kubernetes cluster and must be protected accordingly. Enable encryption at rest using the API server's encryption provider configuration.
Access to etcd should be strictly limited to the API server. Ensure mutual TLS is enabled, and never expose etcd directly to the network.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 242, 166), rgb(45, 34, 0)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(182, 138, 0), rgb(156, 119, 0));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Operators and Infrastructure Workloads

Operators act on custom Kubernetes resources (e.g., Certificates) via standard
controllers. They typically run as Deployments and require RBAC access to specific APIs.

Treat operators like any other workload: apply strict access controls,
run them on dedicated nodes if needed, and isolate privileges based on
least privilege principles." tags="pri-2" slug="cert-manager"/>
g.data-help:
Operators and Infrastructure Workloads
Operators act on custom Kubernetes resources (e.g., Certificates) via standard controllers. They typically run as Deployments and require RBAC access to specific APIs.
Treat operators like any other workload: apply strict access controls, run them on dedicated nodes if needed, and isolate privileges based on least privilege principles.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Kubernetes Distributions and OS Choices

Choose a Kubernetes distribution and OS designed for security and minimal
attack surface. Avoid general-purpose OSes that require separate patching.

Consider immutable, minimal, and hardened distros (e.g., Talos, Flatcar,
Bottlerocket) purpose-built for Kubernetes production environments." tags="pri-2" slug="cluster"/>
g.data-help:
Kubernetes Distributions and OS Choices
Choose a Kubernetes distribution and OS designed for security and minimal attack surface. Avoid general-purpose OSes that require separate patching.
Consider immutable, minimal, and hardened distros (e.g., Talos, Flatcar, Bottlerocket) purpose-built for Kubernetes production environments.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 209, 161), rgb(85, 46, 4)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(180, 95, 6), rgb(208, 135, 58));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Namespaces

Namespaces are logical boundaries used to apply security controls such as
network policies, RBAC, and runtime restrictions.

While not a security mechanism by themselves, they enable isolation between
workloads and enforce separation of concerns.

Many controls are applied per namespace, including Pod Security Admission
(PSA) profiles, ResourceQuota, LimitRange, NetworkPolicy, and the
default ServiceAccount used by pods unless explicitly overridden.

This makes namespaces important for multi-tenancy, workload isolation,
and applying different security baselines across teams or environments.

Do not confuse Kubernetes namespaces with Linux process namespaces inside containers." slug="namespace"/>
g.data-help:
Namespaces
Namespaces are logical boundaries used to apply security controls such as network policies, RBAC, and runtime restrictions.
While not a security mechanism by themselves, they enable isolation between workloads and enforce separation of concerns.
Many controls are applied per namespace, including Pod Security Admission (PSA) profiles, ResourceQuota, LimitRange, NetworkPolicy, and the default ServiceAccount used by pods unless explicitly overridden.
This makes namespaces important for multi-tenancy, workload isolation, and applying different security baselines across teams or environments.
Do not confuse Kubernetes namespaces with Linux process namespaces inside containers.

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(255, 122, 122), rgb(198, 84, 84)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(122, 20, 20), rgb(255, 183, 183));

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Image Repository

Container images should be scanned for vulnerabilities before being stored in
or pulled from the image repository.

Use tools that enforce image admission policies, signature verification,
and vulnerability thresholds to block untrusted or outdated images." slug="image-repo"/>
g.data-help:
Image Repository
Container images should be scanned for vulnerabilities before being stored in or pulled from the image repository.
Use tools that enforce image admission policies, signature verification, and vulnerability thresholds to block untrusted or outdated images.

<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Default Pod-to-Pod Traffic

By default, all pods can communicate with each other. Use a default-deny
NetworkPolicy to block all traffic, then explicitly allow only necessary
communication between pods.

This is essential for achieving network segmentation and reducing the
blast radius of a compromise." slug="pod-to-pod"/>
g.data-help:
Default Pod-to-Pod Traffic
By default, all pods can communicate with each other. Use a default-deny NetworkPolicy to block all traffic, then explicitly allow only necessary communication between pods.
This is essential for achieving network segmentation and reducing the blast radius of a compromise.

<UserObject label="" help="GatewayAPI Policy Attachment

Policies add behavior to Gateway API resources, such as authentication,
authorization, rate limiting, header manipulation, or security controls.

A policy usually attaches to a target resource (for example a Gateway
or a Route) using a targetRef. The exact policy kinds and supported
targets depend on the Gateway implementation.

Use policies to separate traffic routing (*Route) from operational and
security concerns." tags="pri-2 GatewayApiStack" slug="gateway-api-policy"/>
g.data-help:
GatewayAPI Policy Attachment
Policies add behavior to Gateway API resources, such as authentication, authorization, rate limiting, header manipulation, or security controls.
A policy usually attaches to a target resource (for example a Gateway or a Route) using a targetRef. The exact policy kinds and supported targets depend on the Gateway implementation.
Use policies to separate traffic routing (*Route) from operational and security concerns.

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Cross-Namespace Reference Permission (ReferenceGrant)

ReferenceGrant allows a resource in one namespace to reference a
resource in another namespace, when the Gateway API would otherwise deny
that cross-namespace reference.

It is typically used when a Route in one namespace points to a backend
Service in another namespace.

The ReferenceGrant must be created in the target namespace (the
namespace of the referenced resource), and it explicitly allows which
resource kinds/namespaces may reference it." tags="pri-2 GatewayApiStack" slug="gateway-api-ref-grant"/>
g.data-help:
Cross-Namespace Reference Permission (ReferenceGrant)
ReferenceGrant allows a resource in one namespace to reference a resource in another namespace, when the Gateway API would otherwise deny that cross-namespace reference.
It is typically used when a Route in one namespace points to a backend Service in another namespace.
The ReferenceGrant must be created in the target namespace (the namespace of the referenced resource), and it explicitly allows which resource kinds/namespaces may reference it.

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1 GatewayApiStack" help="Gateway

Kubernetes Gateway resources are part of Gateway API and define how
traffic enters the cluster, including listeners (ports, protocols, hostnames)
and TLS configuration (for example certificate references).

A Gateway is attached to a GatewayClass (implementation/controller) and is
typically used together with Route resources (such as HTTPRoute or
TCPRoute) that define traffic matching and forwarding behavior.

From a security perspective, Gateway is a key enforcement point for exposed
services: it defines which protocols and hostnames are accepted, where TLS is
terminated, and which certificates are used. Additional security controls are
typically attached through policy resources (for example authentication,
authorization, rate limiting, and WAF-related controls), while routes define
how traffic is forwarded.

Gateway API separates infrastructure ownership (GatewayClass / Gateway)
from application routing (*Route) and policy attachment (*Policy), making
it a more structured and extensible model for secure, modern traffic
management.
" slug="gateway"/>
g.data-help:
Gateway
Kubernetes Gateway resources are part of Gateway API and define how traffic enters the cluster, including listeners (ports, protocols, hostnames) and TLS configuration (for example certificate references).
A Gateway is attached to a GatewayClass (implementation/controller) and is typically used together with Route resources (such as HTTPRoute or TCPRoute) that define traffic matching and forwarding behavior.
From a security perspective, Gateway is a key enforcement point for exposed services: it defines which protocols and hostnames are accepted, where TLS is terminated, and which certificates are used. Additional security controls are typically attached through policy resources (for example authentication, authorization, rate limiting, and WAF-related controls), while routes define how traffic is forwarded.
Gateway API separates infrastructure ownership (GatewayClass / Gateway) from application routing (*Route) and policy attachment (*Policy), making it a more structured and extensible model for secure, modern traffic management.

<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1 GatewayApiStack" help="GatewayClass

GatewayClass selects which Gateway API controller implementation manages
a Gateway (for example Envoy Gateway, Kong, Traefik, NGINX Gateway
Fabric, or a cloud-managed implementation).

This is a key trust boundary: controllers differ in supported spec
versions, conformance level, feature maturity, and security/policy
behavior. Gateway API conformance helps validate what is actually
implemented." slug="gatewayclass"/>
g.data-help:
GatewayClass
GatewayClass selects which Gateway API controller implementation manages a Gateway (for example Envoy Gateway, Kong, Traefik, NGINX Gateway Fabric, or a cloud-managed implementation).
This is a key trust boundary: controllers differ in supported spec versions, conformance level, feature maturity, and security/policy behavior. Gateway API conformance helps validate what is actually implemented.

g.content:
<UserObject label="" tags="pri-1" help="Pod Security Admission (PSA)

Pod Security Admission (PSA) enforces a baseline security level for pods
in a namespace by validating pod specs at admission time (before the pod
is created).

It uses namespace labels to apply standard Pod Security profiles
(privileged, baseline, restricted) and can block insecure settings
such as privileged containers, excessive Linux capabilities, unsafe host
access, or other risky pod configurations.

PSA is an important preventive control for reducing attack surface and
stopping insecure workloads before they are deployed." slug="psa"/>
g.data-help:
Pod Security Admission (PSA)
Pod Security Admission (PSA) enforces a baseline security level for pods in a namespace by validating pod specs at admission time (before the pod is created).
It uses namespace labels to apply standard Pod Security profiles (privileged, baseline, restricted) and can block insecure settings such as privileged containers, excessive Linux capabilities, unsafe host access, or other risky pod configurations.
PSA is an important preventive control for reducing attack surface and stopping insecure workloads before they are deployed.

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="ResourceQuota

ResourceQuota limits the total amount of cluster resources a namespace
can consume (for example CPU, memory, storage, and object counts such as
pods or services).

From a security and resilience perspective, quotas help reduce denial-of-service
risk inside the cluster by preventing a single namespace or team from
exhausting shared resources and impacting other workloads.

ResourceQuota is primarily a governance and availability control, but it
also supports multi-tenancy and safer operations by enforcing usage bounds." tags="pri-2" slug="resourcequota"/>
g.data-help:
ResourceQuota
ResourceQuota limits the total amount of cluster resources a namespace can consume (for example CPU, memory, storage, and object counts such as pods or services).
From a security and resilience perspective, quotas help reduce denial-of-service risk inside the cluster by preventing a single namespace or team from exhausting shared resources and impacting other workloads.
ResourceQuota is primarily a governance and availability control, but it also supports multi-tenancy and safer operations by enforcing usage bounds.

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="LimitRange

LimitRange defines default and minimum/maximum resource requests and
limits for containers and pods in a namespace (for example CPU and
memory).

From a security and stability perspective, it helps prevent unsafe or
unbounded workloads (such as containers with no limits) and improves
cluster reliability by enforcing consistent resource settings.

LimitRange is mainly a stability and governance control, but it also
supports safer multi-tenant operation by reducing resource abuse and
misconfiguration." tags="pri-2" slug="limitrange"/>
g.data-help:
LimitRange
LimitRange defines default and minimum/maximum resource requests and limits for containers and pods in a namespace (for example CPU and memory).
From a security and stability perspective, it helps prevent unsafe or unbounded workloads (such as containers with no limits) and improves cluster reliability by enforcing consistent resource settings.
LimitRange is mainly a stability and governance control, but it also supports safer multi-tenant operation by reducing resource abuse and misconfiguration.

g.content:
<UserObject label="<font style="font-size: 18px; color: rgb(51, 51, 51);"><b style="">?</b></font>" help="ResourceQuote vs LimitRange

ResourceQuota limits the total resources and object counts a namespace can use, which helps prevent one team/app from exhausting shared cluster capacity (for example creating too many pods/services or consuming too much CPU, memory, or storage).

LimitRange sets default and min/max resource requests and limits for pods/containers in that namespace, which helps prevent unsafe or unstable workloads (for example containers with no memory limit, or requests/limits that are far too high or too low)." tags="info" slug="resourcequota-limitrange"/>
g.data-help:
ResourceQuote vs LimitRange
ResourceQuota limits the total resources and object counts a namespace can use, which helps prevent one team/app from exhausting shared cluster capacity (for example creating too many pods/services or consuming too much CPU, memory, or storage).
LimitRange sets default and min/max resource requests and limits for pods/containers in that namespace, which helps prevent unsafe or unstable workloads (for example containers with no memory limit, or requests/limits that are far too high or too low).

g.content:
<UserObject label="" help="Default ServiceAccount

Every namespace has a default ServiceAccount, and pods use it automatically unless another ServiceAccount is explicitly configured. From a security perspective, this matters because unintended API access can be granted if the default account has permissions or if service account tokens are auto-mounted unnecessarily." tags="pri-3" slug="default-sa"/>
g.data-help:
Default ServiceAccount
Every namespace has a default ServiceAccount, and pods use it automatically unless another ServiceAccount is explicitly configured. From a security perspective, this matters because unintended API access can be granted if the default account has permissions or if service account tokens are auto-mounted unnecessarily.
